==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}

===Etymology===
This word initially referred to spirit medium/shaman of either sex, but eventually female when contrasted with {{och-l|覡|male shaman}}. Various hypotheses exist regarding its etymology:
# Cognate with {{cog|bo|འབའ་པོ||magician, sorcerer}}, {{m|bo|འབའ་མོ||sorcereress}}.
# Cognate with {{och-l|誣|to deceive}}.
# Cognate with {{och-l|舞|to dance}}.
# Cognate with {{och-l|母|female}}.
# Victor Mair proposes that this is a loanword from {{cog|peo|𐎶𐎦𐎢𐏁|tr=maguš}}, a word represented by the [[☩]] ({{w|cross potent}}) which is graphically similar to the Chinese bronze inscription form ({{zh-ref|Mair, 1990; Mair, 2012}}).

{{cog|th|หมอ||doctor}} < {{cog|tai-pro|*ʰmo:ᴬ||shaman}} is generally assumed to be a Sino-Tibetan loan. More at {{w|Wu (shaman)}}, {{w|Magi#In Chinese sources}}, {{m|en|magus}}.

====Compounds====
{{der-top|Compounds}}

* {{ja-r|巫山|^ふざん}}: [[Wushan]], the Wu Mountains, a [[mountainous]] area in China along the {{w|Wu Gorge}}
* {{ja-r|巫術|ふじゅつ}}: [[shamanism]]; [[witchcraft]], [[sorcery]]
* {{ja-r|巫女|みこ}}: a [[shrine]] [[maiden]]

====Usage notes====
This is the only kanji added to the jinmeiyō kanji list on 7 January 2015 by the Japanese government; previously classified as hyōgaiji.
